answer_html: Because the conclusion of the statement is not necessarily true, the statement is false.

hints_html: What’s the difference between a limit and an evaluation? Try drawing a picture!
hints_latex:
What's the difference between a limit and an evaluation? Try drawing a
picture!
hints_raw: What's the difference between a limit and an evaluation? Try drawing a picture!
question: 2 (c)
sols_html:
Remember that a limit describes the y-values of a graph around, but not at the x-value, whereas \(f(x)\) gives the y-value of a graph at x.

So drawing a picture where \(\lim_{x \to 1} f(x)\) (y-values are equal to 2 near x = 1) could look like this:

But, \(f(1)\), the y-value at x = 1, could be equal to something else, like 1:

Because the conclusion of the statement is not necessarily true, the statement is false.
sols_latex:
Remember that a limit describes the y-values of a graph \textbf{around},
but not \textbf{at} the x-value, whereas $f(x)$ gives the y-value of a
graph \textbf{at} \emph{x}.

So drawing a picture where $\lim_{x \to 1} f(x)$ (y-values are equal to
2 near \emph{x = 1}) could look like this:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_2c_example2.jpg}

But, $f(1)$, the y-value at \emph{x = 1}, could be equal to something
else, like 1:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/December_2012/MER_MATH110_December_2012_Question_2c_example1.jpg}

Because the conclusion of the statement is not necessarily true, the
statement is false.
sols_raw:
Remember that a limit describes the y-values of a graph '''around''', but not '''at''' the x-value, whereas <math>f(x)</math> gives the y-value of a graph '''at''' ''x''.  

So drawing a picture where <math>\lim_{x \to 1} f(x)</math> (y-values are equal to 2 near ''x = 1'') could look like this: 

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 2c example2.jpg|500px]]
 
But, <math>f(1)</math>, the y-value at ''x = 1'', could be equal to something else, like 1:

[[File:MER MATH110 December 2012 Question 2c example1.jpg|500px]]

Because the conclusion of the statement is not necessarily true, the statement is false.
statement_html:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If \(\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow1}f(x)=2\), then \(\displaystyle f(1)=2\).
statement_latex:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is
true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If $\displaystyle \lim_{x\rightarrow1}f(x)=2$, then
$\displaystyle f(1)=2$.
statement_raw:
Determine whether the following statement is true or false. If it is true, provide justification. If it is false, provide a counterexample.

If <math>\displaystyle\lim_{x\rightarrow1}f(x)=2</math>, then <math> \displaystyle f(1)=2</math>.
